newsitem.title: USA: BEFORE THE BELL -- Gen' Instrument gains.
newsitem.headline: BEFORE THE BELL -- Gen' Instrument gains.

text.p: General Instrument Corp's announced plan to split into three separate public companies atrracted investors early Tuesday, sending the stock to 24 from 22-3/4, according to traders.
The company said early this morning that it intends to create three new companies, a move that will result in a charge of $55 to $65 million, or $0.37 to $0.44 per share.
The company expects fourth quarter earnings, which will be announced on February 10, to be in the range of $0.28 to $0.32 per fully-diluted share, excluding the charges.
The restructuring, through a tax-free spin-off to shareholders, is expected to be completed this summer.

The three new companies will be: NextLevel Systems Inc, General Instruments' cable, satellite and telephony businesses with 1996 sales of more than $1.7 billion, CommScope Inc, maker of coaxial cable and supplier of high-performance electronic cables with 1996 sales of more than $560 million and General Semiconductor Inc, now the company's power semiconductor division with 1996 sales of over $360 million.
Document Sciences shares are poised to plummet at the market open after warning last night of a decline in fourth quarter earnings.
Before the market open, the share were quoted to reflect an almost 50 percent reduction in market value at six bid, five ask. The stock finished Monday Nasdaq trade at 10-1/8.

Silicon Graphics shares suffered early, dropping to 24-1/4 from 26-7/8 after announcing last night revenue for the fiscal second quarter will be $825 million, below $899 in pro forma revenue one year ago.
Net earnings for the period are expected to be break-even, it said.
